headline.main: Patents or Poverty? New Debate Over Lack of AIDS Care in Africa

docs.abstract: Question of whether drug patents or poverty is primarily responsible for widespread lack of AIDS treatment in Africa is being hotly debated as World Trade Organization prepares to discuss new rules on patents at summit in Qatar; Drs Amir Attaran (Harvard University) and Lee Gillespie-White (International Intellectual Property Institute) sparked debate with study that concludes that poverty is main deterrent to treatment, noting that only 22 precent of 795 patents theoretically available across Africa have been awarded, in most cases because companies that own patents have not bothered to apply; everyone acknowledges that antiretroviral drugs are still too expensive to be widely obtainable in Africa at prices people can afford (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A new debate has erupted over the epidemic of AIDS in Africa, about whether it is patents or poverty that is primarily responsible for the widespread lack of treatment. The issue has become a major bone of contention as the World Trade Organization prepares to discuss new rules on patents at its summit mmeting in Qatar this week. Professors of medicine, law and economics, who for the most part consider themselves advocates of the poor, are attacking each other over an issue raised by a study published Oct. 17 in the Journal of the American Medical Association.
